job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in San Diego, CA

cons: Staff was burnt out, overworked, underpaid, undervalued, and unappreciated. Incredibly bad leadership at the law school and a lack of true caring for students. No oversight, or compliance regulations were in place, and no training or onboarding.

review_title: University of San Diego Hospitality Review
job_title: Server/Caterer in San Diego, CA
pros: USD had a very flexible work schedule for students. Some straightforward events, easy to set- up and breakdown. For most shifts, you were offered food from the end of the events. Always working with a team, never left to do a huge event alone.
cons: Management was sometimes disorganized so you were left waiting for someone to show up. Temporary staff got paid way more than USD employees which were frustrating because often we were doing more work and explaining to them what to do. Often management was very stressed due to pressure from upper management which trickled down to employees.

job_title: Assistant Professor in San Diego, CA
pros: Good benefits and retirement; friendly work environment
cons: Overworks and underpays its faculty and staff.

review_title: Loving a university that doesn't love you back
job_title: Study Abroad Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: beautiful campus, amazing colleagues, good 403b retirement plan, good health insurance
cons: There is little to no professional development opportunities. The most experienced, passionate, and educated people (and alumni) work in staff positions there, and management and leadership could care less. The disparity in pay is laughable (ie, Deans can make a nice six figure salary while full time staff have to get a second job to pay to live in San Diego), there is little to no WFH flexibility, and you will be exploited and taken advantage of (overworked, overwhelmed, doing work for multiple positions without change in pay). It is all about who you know - HR will favor friends in certain departments, your best friends across campus will leave because of burnout, and no one will ever ask you how you're doing at work or if you need support. I once considered this my dream job, but realized that I loved a job that simply did not love me back.

review_title: Best benefits of any institute of higher Ed in SoCal

10% of annual salary fully vested contribution to your 403B

job_title: Executive Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Paid time off, sick days, holidays off, vacation during Christmas week.
cons: One of the selling points is the ability to apply for tuition remission, but depending on your employer, they will either support you and the time you need to obtain your degree or they won't-in my case I wasn't able to attend the program I wanted because there were classes scheduled in the middle of the work day. You have to pay for parking and I personally experienced age discrimination- being young means more responsibilities are put on you and you "don't get away with things" that older people/people with more seniority do.

job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros:
- Beautiful campus
- Paid time off is generous
- 12% contribution to retirement paid by University (100% vested)
- Tuition remission benefit (The current policy is good. However, it will be changing.)
cons:
- People are fake and condescending
- "Staff" are treated like lower class employees
- Benefits for administrators are far superior
- Health care benefits are expensive
- Highly promoted tuition remission benefit is being limited and the new proposals to limit it further will affect the lower paid employees the most (to the point where many won't be able to take advantage of it).
- Very political and a "gossipy" environment

review_title: Constantly shifting priorities and constant emergencies.
job_title: ITS in San Diego, CA
pros:
Beautiful campus.
12% retirement matching.
Useful perks such as gym membership and other discounts are available with staff ID.
Management reliably offers lunch and/or dinner when emergency issues force people to stay late.
cons:
Management does as much as possible to please everyone, which prevents anything from being done really well.  This leads to constantly shifting priorities.
There is poor organization at all levels.  Resources are added with no thought as to when they will be removed or streamlined.
There is personnel friction between managers resulting in orders being issued and then countermanded.
There is no automated testing of systems and processes.
There are no checklists to confirm that complex systems are "working" or not.
There is no perceived long term career growth path.

job_title: Student Worker in San Diego, CA
pros: Great experience, I learned so much.  I was able to work in so many different departments which helped me become well rounded in terms of my knowledge for the work force.  I was able to learn what kind of offices I liked to work in, and what kinds I did not.
cons: There was a lot of drama, and some of the work environments were hostile.  It is for that reason, and that reason alone that I could not imagine working there further.  I don't think that is the fault of USD, but an inability to recognize the flaws in some of the management and lessen that persons grip on the departments.  If every single person in your building is terrified of one of your managers, it should indicate how well they are managing.

job_title: Human Resources Student Worker in San Diego, CA
pros: It was a great environment to work in and I can honestly say I loved coming to work on most days. This is the only job I have ever had that appreciated everything I do and did their best to support me through my classes and learning the job trade. I cannot thank the university enough for this opportunity, and I am currently looking for other jobs within the university as a result of how much I loved it. Thanks USD!
cons: The only downside to working here was there was a cap on my hours. I am a poor college student looking to make some money and I was capped on 15 hours a week. Granted, this is still a lot of work time, but I would have liked the chance to work an extra hour if I had some free time, or had a day off from classes.

review_title: At least the campus is pretty
job_title: Executive Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros:
12% employer-paid retirement contribution.
Most of the faculty and staff are very welcoming and collegial.
Tuition waiver (a.k.a. tuition remission) is available so employees may take classes at no/reduced cost.
cons:
Almost imperceptible diversity.
Astoundingly low salaries compared to similar positions within higher education fields in San Diego.
No promotional opportunities or room for growth.
Incompetent personnel management coupled with ineffectual administrative leadership at some levels.
Not much in the way of campus-wide process streamlining -- too many fiefdoms.
Conservative cultural and political influences make their way onto this campus a little more than they should.

job_title: Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Beautiful campus, great retirement and tuition remission benefits for employees.
cons: They outsourced and are paying thousands of dollars for a company to take a look at our salaries and budgets (we are a non-profit and already underpaid) so they are starting to consolidating positions (we already do like 5 jobs on top of ours for low pay) and start firing people, just because they want to raise tuition costs which are already extremely high. They will not look into administrators making 6 figure salaries or the coaches (we don't even have a real sports team) yet the coaches make 6 figures. Everyone is afraid of losing their jobs, this is creating very low morale

job_title: Administrator in San Diego, CA
pros: Vacation, benefits, great students, wonderful community.
cons: Absolutely no raises, no room for upward growth even when you've made miracles happen. The bureaucracy is limiting and the leadership does not value the administration. The leadership states there is no budget to increase salaries yet the endowment has grown tremendously and tuition increases annually. The landscape budget is outrageous. The university needs to invest in it's employees too.

review_title: USD the career purgatory for cooks or hospitality workers

pros:

review_title: This review is specific to my department, the university is a great place to work overall
job_title: Admissions Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits, beautiful campus, employee activities
cons: Leadership, no growth opportunities, favoritism

job_title: IT Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Great location, beautiful campus. Great retirement benefits, they deposited 12% in your 403B with no employee contribution required. Can't find a benefit like that at any other institution. Health benefits started out being very good, but was getting progressively worse with higher premiums. Vacation policy was great if you were an exempt employee (5 weeks to start!), not so good if you were non-exempt (2 weeks to start).  Work environment was more relaxed and less hectic; co-workers and other employees were generally great to deal with.
cons:
Extremely low salaries, and very difficult to advance. You have to be comfortable with making 30-40% less than similar jobs in the private sector. Have to pay to park on campus. Though public transportation is subsidized to a small degree, access to campus is difficult as tram service is spotty and inconsistent. Increasing premiums every year on health insurance (when I started health insurance for a single person was free!). Very few opportunities for training as budget was kept tightly controlled

Lack of vision and direction in IT from upper management. Main culprit being an incompetent, non-technical CIO who gets sidetracked by buzzwords and catchphrases and ends up making ill-informed infrastructure decisions. Other directors just simply brown-nose.  Lack of support and protection from immediate management, had to troubleshoot issues that were the responsibility of other teams constantly due to lack of understanding at management level. Investment in infrastructure not done in a sensible manner, certain areas of infrastructure are overspent on, while others are completely neglected.

review_title: Residential Life is such a supportive and caring department with a lot of life experience to learn from.
job_title: Resident Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: The compensation (room and meal plan) and the close relationship with the professional staff are great perks to the Resident Assistant job. The job itself also allows for a lot of personal growth as you are constantly challenged to confront and adapt to unpredictable situations that may occur in the residence halls.
cons: The meal plan could be expanded for Resident Assistants who are living in Freshman areas and do not have kitchens, otherwise it's great!

job_title: Site Coordinator in San Diego, CA
pros: It is a great job with tremendous potential.  Everyone in the office are wonderful people who are not only determined to help you in the field but also help you succeed as an individual.
cons: None.  Absolutely none.  It was a great opportunity.

review_title: Fantastic Colleagues, Beautiful Campus, Awful Students
job_title: Lecturer in San Diego, CA
pros: The administrative staff are extraordinarily warm, the campus is beautiful, classrooms are well equipped, and a handful of the students are very well motivated.
cons: It is a party school for rich kids. Many of the students performed at a very low level and were generally uninterested in non-powerpoint teaching techniques.

review_title: Decent, but not great. Student employee
job_title: ITS in San Diego, CA
pros: ITS jobs aren't horrible. Depending upon the job, it might be able to help you later on and could show that you are tech savvy. Pay is above minimum wage.
cons: Not a whole lot of communication between management and the student workers. And all of the regular cons regarding on-campus jobs (low pay, crappy hours, etc). As an example, I have a friend working in ITS and he had to spend an entire day during Finals week to help fix the wireless network (it crashed for whatever reason).

job_title: Trip Coordinator & Lead Guide in San Diego, CA
pros:
Excellent environment to develop leadership skills.
Team work is necessary and a fantastic part of the experience.
There is room to bring ideas and innovation to the program.
Rewarding service benefits.
cons: There are few downsides, essentially the only one I would have is that the work is not incredibly applicable to all industries. Most hard skills learned are only advantageous for the adventure industry.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in San Diego, CA

cons: Not much room for growth or advancement.  Not much work when school is not in session.

job_title: Associate in San Diego, CA
pros: Great people working at USD! the campus is gorgeous and just being there is very relaxing and motivating. You get to choose your own schedule and as a part-time job.
cons: They pay the minimum wage and there's no chance to move up. You have to know one of the managers in order to get a full time.

review_title: Good place to work if you're not the primary breadwinner in your family
job_title: Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Great benefits, amazing retirement contributions, beautiful place to work, flexible work schedule, lots of paid sick time
cons: Little to no career path or advancement opportunity, paltry salary, poor budget management, PTO is separated into sick time and vacation time, with sick time accrued faster than vacation time.

review_title: I've been both a student and employee here and loved every minute
job_title: Administrative Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: All of the employees here are very nice and helpful. I've also had wonderful supervisors who were great at offering guidance and more than willing to put in a good word for me when I was applying to new positions.
cons: They don't have many staff openings right now which is a bummer as I'd like to work for them again

job_title: Computer Science Tutor in San Diego, CA
pros:
Free service for university students
Tutors hand picked for quality
Provided mentorship and community between students
cons:
No real facilities - basement room and whiteboards
Engineering department had different tech stack and often tutors couldn't assist

review_title: Great job for FULL time student
job_title: Computer Lab Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros:
Get ample amount of time to work on homework and to study (pretty much you are getting paid to study and do homework)
Very laid back enviornment
Always have updated computers for both MAC and PC
cons:
The pay is not ideal; nonetheless, the work is extremely easy
Lab can get pretty busy in spurts, which can take away from your study time

job_title: Teaching Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: They really help you find what you're looking for, and make sure you find a place the fits you correctly.
cons: The pay really sucks then to have to buy food full price on campus gets expensive.

review_title: USD not what it seems to be
job_title: in Escondido, CA
pros: Great location-beautiful scenery-in general folks seem happy. OK 403B
cons: Relatively low wages-Some Deans are terrible- some faculty should not have tenure-too expensive for students--whole campus is disjointed. There have been many hushed up lawsuits. Unless you are a teacher--stay away. More $$$ and advancement can be made elsewhere.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Small community, familiar faces, large social life, constant summertime weather, near the beach, great professors, beautiful campus
cons: Some students have an arrogant ego, many students boast about their wealth, first year you have to live on campus

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: The culture is very welcoming and the employees are there to help each other succeed.
cons: Hard to get in if you do not have connections. Also, most departments are very slow when it comes to hiring.

job_title: ITS Help Desk in San Diego, CA
pros: It was easy to go to work in between classes which is a huge plus because you get more hours while being efficient with the day.
cons: There aren't too many huge career opportunities after, leaving this pretty much a job that you talk about at interviews but don't expect to stay in it after you graduate.

job_title: Food in San Diego, CA
pros: Lots of opportunities and room to grow. I really enjoyed my time here and all the people that worked here.  USD really cares about employees and students.
cons: Hard to jump departments. In order to go up in the chain you need higher education. However over time, you could get both there.

review_title: Institution in transition, not always for the better.
job_title: Assistant Professor in San Diego, CA
pros: Teaching and research are both valued.
cons: Teaching continues to be top priority, especially for those who have made their careers there. Lots of resistance to institutional change.

job_title: Various in San Diego, CA
pros:
Allows Students to receive and practice job skills  
Opportunity to fast and secure advancements
Often low stress environments allow for multi-tasking and development of other office skills
Reliable and efficient supervision and direction
mission based and driven
cons:
low pay
low hours
very typical office environment
strict guidelines and producers limit creativity and freedom at times

review_title: A friendly and supportive work environment
job_title: Department Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: The staff as a whole works together nicely and supports one another so that everyone may perform efficiently
cons: Being a student while also being an employee left little time that wasn't spent on the USD campus, but it is so beautiful that it was easy to get past.

job_title: Event Manager/Scheduler in San Diego, CA
pros: Had my own huge office, beautiful campus, the other Event Manager's and catering staff were wonderful, kind people.
cons: The other people in the building where I worked were rude, insensitive, liked to gossip, and honestly horrible management.

job_title: Executive Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros:
Beautiful campus
Energetic, youthful students 
Highly-matrixed organization
cons:
Very low salaries
Catty middle-management
No room for growth, movement, or promotions
Low employee morale
Feeling that upper management discourages personal expression, new ideas, or confrontation

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Beautiful campus. Great employee benefits.
cons: Low pay campus wide. Auxiliary Services’ management  is unprofessional and demeaning. Employees are overworked and underappreciated, causing a hostile environment.

job_title: Assistant Director in San Diego, CA
pros: Great facility, good parking. Highly thought of school.
cons: Public University with a lot of drama, very unprofessional communication and behavior. HR disconnected from what’s going on

review_title: Strong teams, but teams aren't all working together
job_title: Conference Coordinator in San Diego, CA

cons: Bureaucratic environment, not willing to help departments in other areas of the university if unrelated to own team

review_title: Teaching Assistant at the University of San Diego
job_title: Teaching Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros:
Flexible schedule,
Helpful Professor,
Exciting Material.
This job has allowed me to work 10 hrs/week for $10/hr without preventing me from being able to focus on my studies.
cons: You will be expected to keep on top of your work without guidance.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: great benefits and overall great environment to work due to the faculty and student population always engaging in learning experiences.

review_title: Pleasant, but not spectacular. Just a place to get a paycheck and move on.
job_title: Research Intern in San Diego, CA
pros: Beautiful city and campus. Not very stressful.
cons: Not really a place to stay long-term. Pay could have been better as well.

job_title: Sales Associate in San Diego, CA

cons: Sometimes you do not get as much hours as you would like

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: If interested in teaching at a university, USD is a good place.
cons: Department heads tend to be 'yes' people in my unit.

job_title: Career Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: It's a pleasure to be able to work with so many great students, staff, faculty, and administrators.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in San Diego, CA

cons: Not a ton of growth potential, but that was ok, as a student it was the perfect job and acted as a great spring board to other jobs.

review_title: Great place to work...however politics can be challenging
job_title: Manager in San Diego, CA

job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: Beautiful environment, good benefits, events on campus.

job_title: Program Coordinator in San Diego, CA

-Limited upward mobility
-Old school leadership, incredibly slow institutional systems

review_title: Lots of hours at first but it slows down
job_title: Retail Sales Associate in San Diego, CA

job_title: Academic Coordinator in San Diego, CA

Pay is low
Parking
Medical benefits lacking

job_title: Counselor in San Diego, CA

review_title: Work-Study is the way to go

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA

a lot of entertainment discounts, such as amc, seaworld, legoland, disneyland and such
get all the benefits of being a student

job_title: Assistant Coordinator in San Diego, CA

job_title: Receptionist in San Diego, CA

review_title: Progressive and Proactive Institution in furthering educations

review_title: Great place to work as a student

review_title: Fair, caring, supportive and forward thinking.
job_title: Graduate Assistant in San Diego, CA
